discussion.content:
depends on the user who locked:
Step 3 Use the no zone commit vsan <vsan id> force command on the switch that holds the lock to release the lock if another user holds the lock.


Note Verify that no valid configuration change is in progress before you clear a lock.

Step 4 If problems persist, use the clear zone lock command to remove the lock from the switch. This should only be done on the switch that holds the lock.

choices.D: Use theno zone commit vsan <vsan id> forcecommand on the switch that holds the lock to release the lock if another user holds the lock.
choices.C: Use theshow zone internal vsan 16commandto determine the IP address of the user and MDS switch where the lock is currently held.
choices.E: Use theno zone commitvsancommand on the switch that holds the lock to release the lock if you are the holder of the lock.
choices.B: Using either Cisco Fabric Manager or the CLI, reactivate the existing zone set for VSAN 16. Be careful to only reactivate and not deactivate activate to avoid a disruption in service.
choices.A: Use theclear zone lockcommand to remove the lock. Use this command on each switch in thefabric for VSAN 16 only.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are considered best practice when configuring an NFS appliance port on Cisco UCS? (Choose three.)
questions.answer_description:
Why Appliance Port VLANs Should be Allowed on Uplinks There are number of reasons why an upstream switch should allow storage appliance port traffic.
These include:
✑ If storage must be accessed outside of the UCS domain.
✑ If storage and servers are located in different subnets.
✑ If storage is configured in Active/Passive mode and both fabric interconnects require communication to the same controller.
✑ Incertain failover scenarios.
References:

choices.B: If storage and servers are located in the same subnets, then the appliance port VLANs should be allowed on the upstream switch.
choices.A: If storage isconfigured in active/passive mode and both fabric interconnects require communication to the same controller, then the appliance port VLANs should be allowed on the upstream switch.
choices.F: Configuration of the VLAN tagging on the storage side and on the Cisco UCS side simultaneously is recommended.
choices.D: If storage must be accessed outside of the Cisco UCS domain, then the applianceport VLANs should be allowed on the upstream switch.
choices.C: Use of the same VLAN for multiple storage protocol traffic is highly recommended in converse VLAN namespace use.
choices.E: Cisco UCS supports Static and Link Aggregation Control Protocol port channels for appliance port configuration. However, no virtual port-channel support.

discussion.content:
Reference:
http://www.tbijlsma.com/2012/03/how-ucs-achieves-80gbe-of-bandwidth-per-blade/

The reference clearly explains why 80 GB per server is only possible with 2208 IO modules.
Therefore I think that A+B are the correct answers. Not sure if "Fabric Extender" is a typo
and should be replaced by PortExtender.

choices.C: Install 2204 IOMs, VIC1280 CNAs, fabric extenders, and create four vNICs mapped to each fabric.
choices.B: Install 2208 IOMs, VIC1280 CNAs, fabric extenders, and create eight vNICs mapped to each fabric.
choices.D: Install 2204 IOMs, VIC1280 CNAs, and create four vNICs mapped to each fabric.
choices.A: Install 2208 IOMs, VIC1280 CNAs, fabric extenders, and create four vNICs mapped to each fabric.
choices.E: Install 2204 IOMs, VIC1240 CNAs, and create four vNICs mappedto each fabric.
choices.F: Install 2204 IOMs, VIC1280 CNAs, fabric extenders, and create four vNICs mapped to each fabric.

questions.question_text: You want to make 80 Gbps of bandwidth available to your RedHat servers. Which two statements are true? (Choose two.)

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which statement about this output from two different switches is true?

choices.A: Based on this exhibit, a zone merge problem will not occur, but a warning is generated that indicates that some minor differences in the zone set exist.
choices.D: There is no way to tell if a zone merge problem will be encountered with just the current display. Additional commands will need to be performed in order to determine if a problem exists.
choices.B: This exhibit shows no problem. No zone merge issues occur for VSAN 1 based on thecurrent displays.
choices.C: Based on this exhibit. a zone merge problem will occur.

discussion.content:
based on reference:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/mds9000/sw/6_2/configuration/guides/fabric/nx-os/nx_os_fabric/zone.html

When there is a mismatch in default-zoning policies between two switches (permit on one side and deny on the other), zone merge will fail. The behavior is the same between two Brocade switches as well. The error messages will be as shown below.

The error messages will be as shown below:

Switch1 syslog:

switch(config-if)# 2014 Sep 2 06:33:21 hac15 %ZONE-2-ZS_MERGE_FAILED: %$VSAN 1%$ Zone merge failure, isolating interface fc2/10 received reason: Default zoning policy conflict. Received rjt from adjacent switch:[reason:0]

Switch2 syslog:

switch(config-if)# 2014 Sep 2 12:13:17 hac16 %ZONE-2-ZS_MERGE_FAILED: %$VSAN 1%$ Zone merge failure, isolating interface fc3/10 reason: Default zoning policy conflict.:[reason:0]

so through elimination the answer is C

Reference:
https://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/ps5989/prod_troubleshooting_guide_chapter09186a008067a309.html#wp29190

The two outputs have different default zone policies (deny vs. permit), but I am not sure if this is sufficient for a clear merge problem (Answer C)
